example03StringStripIndent() - Method in class com.github.kbnt.java14.tb.TextBlocks
The text blocks feature is processed by the compiler in a particular way (full description in the mentioned JEP document section called Compile-time processing).
Several APIs have been added that mimic this behavior and one of them is called stripIndent().
example03SwitchAsExpressionAndYield() - Method in class com.github.kbnt.java14.se.SwitchExpressions

example04Autoboxing() - Method in class com.github.kbnt.java14.npe.HelpfulNPEMessages
 
example04Inception() - Method in class com.github.kbnt.java14.tb.TextBlocks
This is an ironical example making a reference to the Inception movie and the idea of a "dream in a dream".

The example builds a SQL statement using the JS build in engine leveraging JavaScript's ES6 template literals all defined as text blocks in Java.

The irony and analogy to the mentioned movie comes from the fact that: First, we demo the text blocks as a Java feature.
example04SwitchAsExpressionExhaustiveness() - Method in class com.github.kbnt.java14.se.SwitchExpressions
When we leverage the switch statement as an expression to collect the result, we need to be exhaustive.
example05Java14NewEscapeSequences() - Method in class com.github.kbnt.java14.tb.TextBlocks
The text blocks feature was in the preview mode since Java 13.

Given the fact that the feature eliminates incidental white space and leverages multilines, two concerns occurred: What happens if a developer intentionally wants spaces at the beginning and at the end of the line? For this \s was introduced as an escape sequence to act "as a fence".

The pattern matching for instanceof (JEP 305) feature allows us to test if a reference is an instance of a class and cast it in "one shot" eliminating one line of boilerplate cast.

R

Records - Class in com.github.kbnt.java14.records
Record properties (as per JEP 359): private final field for each component; public read accessor method for each component of the state description, with the same name and type as the component; a public constructor, whose signature is the same as the state description, which initializes each field from the corresponding argument; implementations of equals and hashCode that say two records are equal if they are of the same type and contain the same state; implementation of toString that includes the string representation of all the record components, with their names; cannot extend any other class; cannot declare instance fields other than the private final fields which correspond to components of the state description; any other fields which are declared must be static; implicitly final; cannot be abstract; are shallowly immutable.
Records() - Constructor for class com.github.kbnt.java14.records.Records
